Operation 'EraseRecipientEmailData' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. The original summary 'Erase recipients' email data' is too generic and doesn't convey that this is an asynchronous job submission. The description, while comprehensive, lacks clarity about the asynchronous nature and return value (202 with job ID). Improved summary emphasizes the job submission aspect. Enhanced description clarifies: (1) the asynchronous nature of the operation, (2) input constraints and validation behavior, (3) specific data fields deleted, (4) account scoping and Subuser handling, and (5) the 202 response with job ID for AI agents to understand the operation's workflow and expected outcomes.

data.current_description:
This operation allows you to delete your recipients' personal email data

The Delete Recipients' Email Data operation accepts a list of 5,000 `email_addresses` or a total payload size of 256Kb per request, whichever comes first. Upon a successful request with this operation, SendGrid will run a search on the email addresses provided against the SendGrid system to identify matches. SendGrid will then delete all personal data associated with the matched users such as the recipients' names, email addresses, subject lines, categories, and IP addresses.

All email addresses are filtered for uniqueness and tested for structural validity—any invalid addresses will be returned in an error response.

Please note that recipient data is deleted for the account making the request only—deletions do not cascade from a parent account to its Subusers' recipients. To delete a Subuser's recipients' data, you can use the `on-behalf-of` header.
data.summary_suggestion: Submit recipient data erasure job request
data.description_suggestion: Submits an asynchronous job to erase personal data for specified recipients from the Twilio SendGrid platform. Accepts up to 5,000 email addresses or 256KB payload per request (whichever limit is reached first). The operation validates email addresses for structural validity and filters for uniqueness; invalid addresses are returned in the error response. Upon successful submission, SendGrid searches for matching recipients and deletes all associated personal data including names, email addresses, subject lines, categories, and IP addresses. Data deletion is scoped to the authenticated account only and does not cascade to Subusers' recipients; use the `on-behalf-of` header to erase Subuser recipient data. Returns a 202 Accepted response with a job ID for tracking the asynchronous erasure process.

The description, while comprehensive, lacks clarity about the asynchronous nature and return value (202 with job ID). Improved summary emphasizes the job submission aspect. Enhanced description clarifies: (1) the asynchronous nature of the operation, (2) input constraints and validation behavior, (3) specific data fields deleted, (4) account scoping and Subuser handling, and (5) the 202 response with job ID for AI agents to understand the operation's workflow and expected outcomes.
